content.raw: This code, along with most changes to finish\_train, were moved from proc\_train\_results which performed a similar function. From my understanding, max\_params will be the training instance data from the best instance. check\_filenames will be its filenames, for the best params.params, etc. If this instance failed, no filenames would be output and present. I don’t know how this indicates all failed rather than just the best instance.

I don’t know how this indicates all failed rather than just the best instance.

content.raw: I miswrote this reply, train.run and train.finish can both be set only in the case that we are running all of train. If this is the case, we don’t need to load the results from training to finish.

content.raw:
@mjmm13 this is ready for your revision.

A few big points since this will have to go through another revision:

* Make sure you run your code through a linter like `flake8` or `Pylint` before resubmission.
* More generous comments and docstrings would be _very_ appreciated. There are some significant changes here that are not-so-obvious to me.
* If it all possible, remove the asserts and replace with an actual realistic error message. At the very least comment as to what the assertion is supposed to catch.

Please clean up the `--help` interface:

```shell
$ segway --help
usage: segway [GLOBAL_OPTION] TASK [TASK_OPTION]GENOMEDATA [GENOMEDATA ...] TRAINDIR [IDENTIFYDIR]

  {,train-init,train-run,train-finish,train-run-round,identify-init,identify-run,identify-finish,posterior-init,posterior-run,posterior-finish,train,identify,posterior,identify+posterior}
    ¦   ¦   ¦   ¦   ¦   Segway Tasks
    
...
```

content.html: Remove accidental trailing whitespace

content.raw: Could you describe the rational for the “results” folder? Looking at the train\_results.0.tab file it’s clear there’s some tracking of results on a per-instance basis although it’s not clear what specifically needs to be kept track of. What information needs to be stored here that can’t be inferred from looking at the contents of other directories?
content.html: Could you describe the rational for the “results” folder? Looking at the train_results.0.tab file it’s clear there’s some tracking of results on a per-instance basis although it’s not clear what specifically needs to be kept track of. What information needs to be stored here that can’t be inferred from looking at the contents of other directories?

content.raw:
The results folders will contain tab files for each instance. These will store everything previously passed to finish through the instance\_params variable. This means that each one will store the best log likelihood \(or the best validation log likelihood if that was selected\), as well as the params file that goes with it. Lastly, it contains the various filenames used to generate the results: the input master and validation files. If we want to get rid of this folder, these could certainly be determined from the other files in the traindir, I just thought this was simpler for loading and reading between run and finish if you were interested in the results of the various instances.

‌

I have updated the docstring for TrainResults to better reflect what this file actually does, since it is just that class written out.
content.html:
The results folders will contain tab files for each instance. These will store everything previously passed to finish through the instance_params variable. This means that each one will store the best log likelihood (or the best validation log likelihood if that was selected), as well as the params file that goes with it. Lastly, it contains the various filenames used to generate the results: the input master and validation files. If we want to get rid of this folder, these could certainly be determined from the other files in the traindir, I just thought this was simpler for loading and reading between run and finish if you were interested in the results of the various instances.

‌

I have updated the docstring for TrainResults to better reflect what this file actually does, since it is just that class written out.

content.raw: OK. That makes sense to me. I suppose having more information about each instance, especially in the case of validation or minibatch might be useful. If @hoffman approves of these intermediate result files then I’m okay with this too. If they do get approved the “Workdir files” in doc/technical.rst will need to be updated.
content.html: OK. That makes sense to me. I suppose having more information about each instance, especially in the case of validation or minibatch might be useful. If @hoffman approves of these intermediate result files then I’m okay with this too. If they do get approved the “Workdir files” in doc/technical.rst will need to be updated.

content.raw: isn’t `getattr(options, "observations")` the same as `options.observations`? If you’re looking for a default value - aren’t the defaults set in the `Runner` `__init__` function?
content.html: isn’t getattr(options, "observations") the same as options.observations? If you’re looking for a default value - aren’t the defaults set in the Runner __init__ function?

content.raw: This is an issue created by splitting the options by steps in argparse. Now these attributes only appear when the step is specified, meaning, in this case the options object will only have “observations” when train-run is selected. This means that when options.observations is called as before, an error would be called, since it does not exist. This was used as a workaround, returning None if the options object does not have observations. This issue is the cause for the changes to track as well.
content.html: This is an issue created by splitting the options by steps in argparse. Now these attributes only appear when the step is specified, meaning, in this case the options object will only have “observations” when train-run is selected. This means that when options.observations is called as before, an error would be called, since it does not exist. This was used as a workaround, returning None if the options object does not have observations. This issue is the cause for the changes to track as well.

content.raw: Doesn’t the argument parser have a default of None for these cases?
content.html: Doesn’t the argument parser have a default of None for these cases?

content.raw: Argparse will return an object containing values for all the options which apply to that task, setting them to none if there is nothing specified in the cmdline. The issue here is that observations does not apply to identify and so when we run segway identify at this point the options.observation object will not exist since that wasn’t a valid option for this task.
content.html: Argparse will return an object containing values for all the options which apply to that task, setting them to none if there is nothing specified in the cmdline. The issue here is that observations does not apply to identify and so when we run segway identify at this point the options.observation object will not exist since that wasn’t a valid option for this task.
